events.title: The Killam Seminar Series: Microfluidic tools for studying cell-cell interactions
events.location: De Grandpre Communications Centre,3801 Rue University Montréal, QC H3A 2B4
events.details: Iain C. Clark is an Assistant Professor in the Bioengineering Department at the University of California, Berkeley, and a faculty affiliate at the California Institute for Quantitative Biosciences. Research in the Clark lab combines tools from multiple disciplines - molecular biology, microfluidics, engineering, and bioinformatics - to study infectious diseases, central nervous system inflammation, and neural circuit connectivity.
events.registration: Registration for lunch with Killam lecturer: https://forms.office.com/r/3uqZXJZw6D?origin=QRCode, Registration is required to attend the lecture in-person https://www.eventbrite.ca/e/the-killam-seminar-series-tickets-779451870527?aff=oddtdtcreator, link to watch the lecture live stream https://vimeo.com/event/2446006

events.title: Targeting Therapeutic Vulnerabilities in Stem-like Glioblastoma Cells
Decoding Signaling Networks at the Brain Tumor-Host Interface

presenters.name: Dr. Ryuhjin Ahn
presenters.affiliation: Koch Institute for Integrative Cancer Research, MIT

events.location: Bernard M. Bloomfield Lecture Hall (Room F-4), Lady David Institute, 3755 Chem. de la Côte-Sainte-Catherine, Montréal, QC H3T 1E1
events.details: Dr. Ryuhjin Ahn, Ph.D. (Koch Institute for Integrative Cancer Research, MIT) recently completed her Postdoctoral Fellowship, focusing on the cancers of the central nervous system, systems biology using mass spectrometry (MS), and multi-omics approaches under the mentorship of Dr. Forest White.  From a single cell perspective, she uses an integrated proteomics tool (called INSIGHT) and is interested in developing new tools to advance the in vivo mapping of signaling networks that govern brain and cancer biology, to enable single-cell spatial phosphoproteomics by mass spectrometry. Her talk is part of a recruitment initiative for single cell neurobiology (made possible by the Ludmer), and the title of her talk is “Decoding Signaling Networks at the Brain Tumor-Host Interface”. It will be an excellent presentation by a rising star in our field!
events.registration: Watch the lecture live stream via Zoom, Meeting ID: 897 6208 5890, Passcode: 158138

events.title: Spatial Transcriptomic Discussion
events.location: Jeanne Timmins Amphitheatre at The Neuro 3801 Rue University, Montréal, QC H3A 2B4
events.details: The event will commence with a presentation by Dr. Charles Couturier on the molecular and spatial molecular landscape of glioblastoma. The program will then proceed with a panel discussion which will include McGil single cell new recruits: Dr. Simon Thebault, MD, PhD (immunology and rare cell identification) and Dr. Loïc Binan, PhD (Cancer and Perturb-seq).
events.registration: Attendance is free but registration is required

events.title: Olszewski Lecture: Spatially Resolved Single-Cell Genomics & Cell Atlas of the Brain

presenters.name: Dr. Xiaowei Zhuang
presenters.affiliation: Howard Hughes Medical Institute, Harvard University

events.location: De Grandpre Communications Centre,3801 Rue University Montréal, QC H3A 2B4
events.details: Cell and tissue functions arise from the coordinated activities of thousands of different genes. Understanding these functions requires imaging at the genome scale, which advances knowledge in many areas of biology, from the regulation of gene expression in cells to the development of cell fate and the organization of cell types in complex tissues. A single-cell genome-scale imaging method, multiplexed error-robust fluorescence in situ hybridization (MERFISH), was developed to enable spatially resolved single-cell transcriptomics, epigenomics, 3D-genomics, and functional genomics. This method allows for single-cell gene-expression profiling in intact tissues, facilitating the identification, spatial mapping, and functional investigation of distinct cell types within those tissues. Using this approach, molecularly defined, spatially resolved, and functionally annotated cell atlases of the brain have been created. This lecture will describe the MERFISH technology and its applications, with a particular focus on mapping the molecular, spatial, and functional organizations of distinct cell types in the brain.
events.registration: Registration is required to attend in person.

events.title: Single Cell Workshop

chairs.name: Dr. Moein Yaqubi
chairs.affiliation: Post-doctoral Scholar, Stratton lab, The Neuro

chairs.name: Dr. Rhalena Thomas
chairs.affiliation: Research Associate, Fon lab and The Neuro EDDU

presenters.name: Please see the agenda for speaker details

events.location: Jeanne Timmins Amphitheatre & Foyer, The Neuro, 3801 University Street, Montreal
events.details: On behalf of the Single Cell Club, you are kindly invited to apply for the Single Cell Workshop 2025. The workshop will cover wet and dry lab aspects of single cell sequencing techniques. Topics will include: sample preparation, detailed analysis workflows, data management, and open science resources. The workshop is designed for those who have a basic knowledge of single cell techniques and a basic knowledge of coding. Thanks to our sponsors, the workshop is free, however, spots are limited. Participants will be selected based on coding experience and other criteria (see application form). Please fill out the application form by April 30th 2025 to be considered as a participant. We will contact you through the email address you provide in the application form if you have been accepted to the workshop by the end of April 2025. For any further questions, please send an email to the event chairs using the subject line Single Cell Workshop 2025.
events.registration: Attendance is free, food is included. Competitive application process is required.

events.location: Jeanne Timmins Amphitheatre & Foyer, The Neuro, 3801 University Street, Montreal
events.details: Our upcoming two day workshop will focus on understanding the wet-lab and dry-lab aspects of this technique. Specifically, the participants will perform a mock experiment in the lab and they will learn how to analyze the data from the primary demultiplexing step through CellRanger and the subsequent quality control, clustering, annotation, differentially expressed genes analysis using Seurat package.

events.location: Thompson House, 3650, Mc Tavish St, Montreal, H3A 1Y2
events.details: This session will cover how analyses of single cell RNA sequencing data using pseudo time trajectory or velocity analysis can be used to understand cell lineages. It will demonstrate and discuss when to use such a computational approach, what computational packages (such as Monocle and Velocyto) to choose from and how to use them for cell ordering.
